STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
December 6, 2021
Angela Aufdemberge
Sisters of Good Shepherd
20651 West Warren
Dearborn Heights, MI 48127
RE: License #: CB820201485
Vista Maria Foster Care
20651 W Warren Avenue
Dearborn Heights, MI 48127
Dear Ms. Aufdemberge:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 11/9/2021.
The exit conference occurred 11/16/2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing
rules, sections of the contract and Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan (ISEP)
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 860-0787.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT

License #: CB820201485
Licensee Name: Sisters of Good Shepherd
Licensee Address: 20651 West Warren
Dearborn Heights, MI 48127
Licensee Telephone #:

Name of Facility: Vista Maria Foster Care
Facility Address: 20651 W Warren Avenue
Dearborn Hts, MI 48127
Facility Telephone #: (313) 271-3050
Original Issuance Date: 02/01/1990
Service Types:

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all of the following:
(d) Staff qualifications.
The agency requires all employees to have a tuberculosis
screening before hire and annually thereafter.
One of eight new employee records reviewed showed the
employee’s tuberculosis administration and reading occurred
8/4/2021 and 8/6/2021 respectively. Almost a month after the
employee’s 7/13/2021 date of hire.
R 400.12205 Required Staff.
(5) An agency shall appoint a social service worker who
possesses at least a bachelor's degree from an accredited
college or university with a major in a human behavioral
science, or in another major where 25% of the course credits
earned toward the degree are in human behavioral sciences.
One of eight new employee records reviewed showed the
employee was hired as a foster care specialist on 7/12/2021.
This was prior to the employee’s obtainment of a bachelor’s
degree on 8/11/2021.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2021.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(d) Three references obtained from persons who are unrelated
to the staff person.
One of eight new employee records reviewed did not show
documentation of references for the employee.
4

Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(f) If the employee has criminal convictions, the chief
administrator or his or her designee shall complete a written
evaluation of the convictions that addresses the nature of the
conviction, the length of time since the conviction, and the
relationship of the conviction to regulated activity.
(g) A written statement from the employee regarding any
convictions.
(f):
Two of eight new employee records reviewed did not show
documentation of a written evaluation by the agency related to
one employee’s ICHAT record of a 2005 incident of operating
on a suspended or revoked license; and another employee’s
2015 ICHAT documentation related to a disorderly person
conviction.
(g):
One of eight new employee records reviewed did not show
documentation of a written statement from the employee related
to a 2005 issue of operating on a suspended or revoked license.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
Four of 18 employee records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One record showed the employee’s six-month evaluation
due by 7/15/2021 was completed late on 8/16/2021.
 Two other records showed the employee’s 2020 annual
evaluation was completed late on 8/20/2021.
 A fourth record did not show document of annual
evaluation due in April 2021.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2020.
5

R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
One of eight open foster home records reviewed, and one of
three closed foster home records reviewed did not show
documentation that the home was provided an application 60
days prior to the respective home’s 12/15/2020 and 9/6/2021
license expiration date.
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(2) The foster parent/agency agreement shall contain all of the
following provisions:
(e) The role of the lawyer guardian ad litem and the court.
Eight of eight open foster home records reviewed showed the
foster parent/agency agreement did not contain (e) as required
by the rule.
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
In one of eight open foster home records reviewed the foster
parent’s first aid recertification due by 4/2/2021 was not
documented.
R400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of three closed foster home records reviewed showed the
licensing recommendation was not submitted to the department
at least 15 days before the respective foster home’s licensing
expiration date. Closure of the license was requested 18 days
after the home’s 9/6/2021 expiration date.
6

Repeat Violation- Interim 2019.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons
interviewed, and names of the interviewers. If children are
interviewed, their last names shall not be included in the report
Two of six special evaluations reviewed did not show clear and
consistent documentation of all persons interviewed and or the
interviewer.
R400.12327 Special evaluation.
(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(a) Provide the foster parent with a copy of the report required
by subrule (5) of this rule within 10 calendar days of its
completion.
(b) Inform the foster parent, in writing, that he or she has a right
to have his or her written response included as an attachment to
the report required by subrule (5) of this rule.
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker
that has children placed in the home.
(a) &(b):
Five of six special evaluation records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) and (b), as required by the rule.
(c):
Five of six special evaluation records reviewed did not show
documentation that the social service worker(s) who had
children placed in the home were provided a copy of the report.
R400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed corrective
action plan, all social service workers who have children placed
in the home shall be notified there is a corrective action plan
and what is required of the foster parent in that plan.
7

One of six special evaluation records reviewed did not show
documentation of (7) as required by the rule.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the
time of the change in placement and the needs that remain to
be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
Two of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a) and (b) as required by the rules.
R400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental treatment and any treatment for a
child who is less than 4 years of age and older, including both of
the following:
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every 18
months, unless a greater frequency is indicated
One eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s
dental examination due by 3/28/2021 was completed five days
late on 4/2/2021.
R400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
(a):
One of two initial service plans reviewed was 40 days late.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2020, Interim 2019.
(b):
Seven of 30 updated service plans (USP) reviewed were late:
8

One child’s:
 12/4/2020-3/3/2021 USP was completed six days late on
3/9/2021.
 3/4/2021-6/1/2021 USP was completed one day late on
6/2/2021.
A second child’s:
 11/29/2020-2/26/2021 USP was completed four days late
on 3/2/2021.
 2/27/2021-5/27/2021 USP was completed three days late
on 5/30/2021.
 5/28/2021-8/25/2021 USP was completed one day late
on 8/26/2021.
A third child’s:
 1/8/2021-4/7/2021 USP was completed 33 days late on
5/10/2021.
 4/8/2021-7/6/2021 USP was completed 55 days late on
8/30/2021.
Repeat Violation – Renewal 2020.
R400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing
agency to another child placing agency, a modified service plan
must be completed within 30 calendar days of the change in
agency responsibility if no other plan is done within 30 days.
The plan shall address why the agency responsibility changed
and whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
In one of eight open foster child records and one of five
independent living youth records reviewed, where the case
transferred to the agency, the record did not show
documentation of a modified service plan, as required by the
rule.
R400.12507 Medical/dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living
receives any needed medical, dental, and mental health care as
required in R400.12413. Medical, dental, and mental health
provided shall be documented in the youth’s record.
Two of five records reviewed did not show compliance:
9

 One record showed documentation of a 6/18/2019
medical examination and not another until 11/15/2021.
 A second record showed the youth’s annual medical
examination due by 5/9/2021 was completed late on
6/11/2021.
R400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the
youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
Four of five youth records reviewed showed independent living
contracts signed by the youth and agency which did not list the
agency’s responsibility.
Repeat Violation- Interim 2019.
R400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of five youth records reviewed did not show documentation
of a December 2020, March 2021, or June 2021 contract.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
Various open foster child and independent living youth records
did not show consistent MISACWIS uploads of all signed
service plans, parent agency treatment plan agreements, FTM
DHS-1105, DHS-69s and or medical passport documentation, at
the time of review.
10

Additionally, various enrolled home records did not show
consistent uploads of required documents.
ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care
provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport, which must
contain the information required by MCL 722.954c(2) and DHHS
Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any successor policies
approved by the Monitors). And at least quarterly thereafter, an
updated Medical Passport must be prepared, as required by the
“Medical Passports” section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-
1-2015) (or any successor policy approved by the Monitors) and
provided to the foster care provider.
Two of five youth records reviewed did not show compliance:
 One record did not show documentation of an April and
July 2021 medical passport.
 A second did not show documentation of a May 2021
medical passport.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2020.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
ADM 300 Child adoption assessment.
Child adoption assessment completed within 45 days of case
acceptance.
In one of six adoption records reviewed, the child’s adoption
assessment was due by 10/12/2020 and completed late on
1/19/2021.
ADM 330 Quarterly progress reports.
Quarterly progress reports (DHHA-614) are to be completed
each quarter.
One of six adoption records reviewed showed the child’s
7/9/2021 quarterly adoption progress reported was completed
late per supervisory approval on 8/5/2021.
11

Repeat Violation- Interim 2019.
FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as outlined in the following table:
 Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Three of eight open foster child records and one of five
independent living youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
 The youth’s record did not show documentation of an
FTM for the youth’s USP 3/5/2021-6/2/2021. One was
completed earlier than required on 4/2/2021. A DHS-
1105 form for that FTM was not documented.
 A second record did not show documentation of an FTM
for the child’s 11/4/2020-12/3/2020 ISP. Nor the child’s
12/4/2020-3/3/2021 USP; one was completed after the
latter reporting period on 3/8/2021.
 A third record did not show documentation of an FTM for
the child’s 2/27/2021-5/27/2021 USP. One was
completed earlier than required on 4/1/2021.
 A fourth record did not show documentation of an FTM
for the child’s 1/8/2021-4/7/2021 USP. Nor an FTM for
this child’s next two USPs.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2020.
FOM 722-6H Documentation of contacts.
All case contacts must be documented in MISACWIS and
indicated in the service plan.
In six of eight open foster child records reviewed the record
contained one or more updated service plans which did not
contain all supervisory meetings or did not list all social work
contacts as listed in MISACWIS’s social work contacts.
12

FOM 722-8C Foster care- Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement.
Signature: When completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate, including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14
and older and in the case of placement agency foster care
cases, the local DHS office designee.
One of 30 updated services plan reviewed showed the youth’s
10/22/2021 signature on the 4/17/2021- 7/14/2021 USP was
more than 30 days after the USP’s approval date.
FOM 722-9 Updated service plan.
Supervisory approval
Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
Report Date.
13 of 30 updated service plans reviewed did not show
compliance:
One youth’s:
 10/29/2020-1/25/2021 USP was completed on 1/25/2021
and approved two days late on 2/10/2021.
 4/26/2021-7/24/2021 USP was completed on 7/24/2021
and approved two days late on 8/9/2021.
A second child’s:
 3/4/2021-6/1/2021 USP was completed on 6/2/2021 and
approved five days late on 6/21/2021.
A third child’s:
 3/4/2021-5/31/2021 USP was completed on 5/31/2021
and approved seven days late on 6/21/2021.
A fourth child’s:
 11/29/2020-2/26/2021 USP was completed on 3/2/2021
and approved three days late on 3/19/2021.
 2/27/2021-5/27/2021 USP was completed on 5/30/2021
and approved three days late on 6/16/2021.
 5/28/2021-8/25/2021 USP was completed on 8/26/2021
and approved seven days late on 9/16/2021.
A fifth child’s
 1/8/2021-4/7/2021 USP was completed on 5/10/2021 and
approved nine days late on 6/2/2021.
13

 4/8/2021-7/6/2021 USP was completed on 8/30/2021 and
approved 14 days late on 9/27/2021.
 7/7/2021-10/3/2021 USP was completed on 10/3/2021
and approved five days late on 10/22/2021.
A sixth child’s
 7/31/2021-10/25/2021 USP was completed on
10/25/2021 and approved two days late on 11/10/2021.
A seventh child’s:
 12/3/2020-3/2/2021 USP was completed on 3/2/2021 and
approved two days late on 3/18/2021.
 3/3/2021-5/31/2021 USP was completed on 5/31/2021
and approved seven days late on 6/21/2021.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R400.12420(1)(e) Updated service plan.
 The agency was apprised it shall clearly and consistently update each
section of the updated service plan.
R400.12420(1)(g) Updated service plan.
 The agency was apprised a behavioral management plan for the child
shall be specific and consistently documented.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Nothing this inspection
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
AND
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first related to the agency’s 2020 Renewal inspection where it received the
following violations:
14

 R400.12205(5) Required Staff.
 R400.12212(3)(a) Personnel records.
 R400.12327(1)(a) &(c) Special evaluation.
 R400.12404(7)(a)-(g) Placement.
 R400.12405(3)(a)-(g) Change of placement.
 R400.12413(1) (c)(ii) Medical and dental policy.
 R400.12418(2)(a) &(b) Development of service plans.
 R400.12421(b) Visitation and parenting time.
 R400.12509(3) Independent living record.
 ISEP 6.30 Supervisory oversight.
 ISEP 6.33 Medical passport.
 SRM 103 Training.
 FOM 722-6B Family team meeting.
 FOM 722-8C Parent agency treatment plan agreement.
 FOM 801 Mental health screening.
The second corrective action plan related to special investigation 2021C0108038
initiated 5/31/2021. The complaint pertained to allegations of nonreceipt of services
for a child; and a foster parent’s nonreceipt of information related to the child at
placement. The investigation found the agency in violation of the following rules and
contract/policy standards:
 R400.12207(3)(a)-Staff responsibilities.
 R400.12404(6)(b), (c) & (7)(a)-(d) & (g)-Placement.
 R400.12409 -Education.
 R400.12411- Clothing policy.
 R400.12417(1)(d)(e)(f) & (2)-Foster parent information.
 FOM 722-6H-Caseworker contact with child in out of home placement.
 FOM 722-9-Updated service plan approval.
 FOM 801- Mental health screening.
 FOM 801- Medical authorization card.
The agency submitted an acceptable action plan on 6/16/2021. The plan appears to be
working in most areas, yet there was a repeat violation this inspection for FOM 722-9.
DCWL ANALYST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
There were no safety alerts indicated this inspection.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
15

November 29, 2021
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
December 6, 2021

Area Manager
16
